stem: The intensive care nurse is reviewing laboratory data for two clients. Based on the documentation in the Electrolyte & Acid-Base Flowsheet, match each set with the correct acid-base interpretation.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 19y/o female following a severe panic attack. She is breathing rapidly (RR 44) and reports tingling in her fingers. 
Patient B: 55y/o male with a small bowel obstruction. He has had an NG tube to low intermittent suction for 48 hours. Reports muscle weakness.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient A: BP 122/78, HR 110, RR 44. 
Patient B: BP 104/62, HR 92, RR 12.

rows.text: pH 7.52, PaCO2 22, HCO3 22 (High pH, Low CO2)
pH 7.55, PaCO2 48, HCO3 38 (High pH, High HCO3)
Presence of circumoral tingling and carpopedal spasm
Presence of hypokalemia (Low K+) and hypochloremia (Low Cl-)

rationale.correct: Respiratory Alkalosis (c1) occurs during hyperventilation where CO2 is 'blown off' (low CO2/r1); clinical signs include tingling and spasms due to low calcium/high pH (r3). Metabolic Alkalosis (c2) occurs when acid is lost (e.g., NG suctioning), leading to high HCO3 levels (r2); it is often accompanied by low potassium and low chloride (r4).
clinicalPearls: In Alkalosis, the pH is high. If the CO2 is low, think LUNGS (Respiratory). If the HCO3 is high, think METABOLIC.
Vomiting/Suction results in loss of HCl (Hydrochloric acid) -> Metabolic Alkalosis.
Hyperventilation results in loss of CO2 (Carbonic acid) -> Respiratory Alkalosis.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that NG suctioning causes metabolic acidosis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Suctioning TAKES AWAY stomach acid. If you take away acid, you are left with ALKALOSIS (Base).

mnemonic.title: Suction Sickness
mnemonic.expansion: Suction starts with S, makes you lose stomach stuff, leads to Metabolic Alkalosis.
